title: unreachable variable is marked unused incorrectly

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Given the following code: [link](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=df9f3e9899dffdea28a8b4ad334046d2)

```rust
pub fn dummy() {
    let mut v = vec![];
    for i in 0..3 {
        unreachable!();
        v.push(i);
    }
}
```

The current output is:

```
warning: unreachable statement
 --> src/lib.rs:5:9
  |
4 |         unreachable!();
  |         -------------- any code following this expression is unreachable
5 |         v.push(i);
  |         ^^^^^^^^^^ unreachable statement
  |
  = note: `#[warn(unreachable_code)]` on by default

warning: unused variable: `v`
 --> src/lib.rs:2:13
  |
2 |     let mut v = vec![];
  |             ^ help: if this is intentional, prefix it with an underscore: `_v`
  |
  = note: `#[warn(unused_variables)]` on by default

warning: unused variable: `i`
 --> src/lib.rs:3:9
  |
3 |     for i in 0..3 {
  |         ^ help: if this is intentional, prefix it with an underscore: `_i`

warning: variable does not need to be mutable
 --> src/lib.rs:2:9
  |
2 |     let mut v = vec![];
  |         ----^
  |         |
  |         help: remove this `mut`
  |
  = note: `#[warn(unused_mut)]` on by default
```

Ideally the output should look like:

```
warning: unreachable statement
 --> src/lib.rs:5:9
  |
4 |         unreachable!();
  |         -------------- any code following this expression is unreachable
5 |         v.push(i);
  |         ^^^^^^^^^^ unreachable statement
  |
  = note: `#[warn(unreachable_code)]` on by default
```

`v` and `i` are marked as unused, but are actually used in `v.push(i)`. `rustc` also suggests removing the `mut` before `v`, which will not compile if `v.push(i)` is reachable. This could be annoying when there are `todo!()`s in code.
